items.title: Russia 'complicating' end to war, says Zelensky as Trump urges Ukraine to agree to Moscow peace deal
items.standfirst: The US president will meet his Ukrainian counterpart in Washington on Monday in the wake of his Alaska summit with Vladimir Putin on Friday.
items.content: The US president will meet his Ukrainian counterpart in Washington on Monday in the wake of his Alaska summit with Vladimir Putin on Friday.

items.title: Ukrainians react to Trump-Putin meeting
items.standfirst: After President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin met in Alaska on Friday, Ukrainians are reacting to the talks that could directly impact them as they continue to face daily attacks from Russia. NBC News’ Richard Engel reports from Kharkiv.
items.content: After President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin met in Alaska on Friday, Ukrainians are reacting to the talks that could directly impact them as they continue to face daily attacks from Russia. NBC News’ Richard Engel reports from Kharkiv.

items.title: Zelenskyy set to visit Trump in Washington on Monday
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said he will discuss ending the war in his homeland with President Trump at the White House on Monday, following a conversation between the two leaders after Trump’s meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin. NBC News’ Vaughn Hillyard has the latest.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said he will discuss ending the war in his homeland with President Trump at the White House on Monday, following a conversation between the two leaders after Trump’s meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin. NBC News’ Vaughn Hillyard has the latest.

Their talks come as Trump aligns himself with Putin, dropping his demand for a ceasefire and backing a comprehensive peace deal hours after meeting with…

items.title: ‘Fear’ in Ukraine following Trump-Putin talks
items.standfirst: Ukrainians have expressed fears that Kyiv’s position is no longer being heard in Washington, says FRANCE 24’s Emmanuelle Chaze, reporting from Kyiv. Following the meeting between President Donald Trump and President Vladimir Putin in Alaska, Ukrainians have noted the failure of the US and Russian leaders to agree on the need for a ceasefire.

items.title: Trump to meet Ukraine’s Zelenskyy after ‘successful’ talks with Putin

items.content: US president changes position on Ukraine, saying he prefers direct peace accord instead of ceasefire after Alaska talks.

items.title: Russia-Ukraine: Is negotiating a peace treaty realistic at this stage in the war?
items.standfirst: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin began with a warm welcome at a US military base in Alaska but ended with a thud Friday (August 15) after they conceded that they had failed to reach any agreements on how to end the Russia-Ukraine war. For more analysis on the summit, FRANCE 24's Erin Ogunkeye is joined by Claude Blanchemaison, Former French Ambassador to Russia.
items.content: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin began with a warm welcome at a US military base in Alaska but ended with a thud Friday (August 15) after they conceded that they had failed to reach any agreements on how to end the Russia-Ukraine war. For more analysis on the summit, FRANCE 24's Erin Ogunkeye is joined by Claude Blanchemaison, Former French Ambassador to Russia.

items.title: How Trump's move away from calls for a Ukraine ceasefire shifts him closer to Putin
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has promised a "Peace Agreement" to end the war in Ukraine following his summit in Alaska with Russian president Vladimir Putin.
items.content: President Donald Trump has promised a "Peace Agreement" to end the war in Ukraine following his summit in Alaska with Russian president Vladimir Putin.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelensky to meet Trump on Monday after Alaska summit fails to secure ceasefire
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said he will meet US President Donald Trump at the White House in Washington on Monday after a Russia-US summit ended without an agreement to stop the fighting in Ukraine. If the meeting goes well, Trump said he would then push for a three-way meeting between Russia, Ukraine and the US to try to seal a "peace agreement".
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said he will meet US President Donald Trump at the White House in Washington on Monday after a Russia-US summit ended without an agreement to stop the fighting in Ukraine. If the meeting goes well, Trump said he would then push for a three-way meeting between Russia, Ukraine and the US to try to seal a "peace agreement".

items.title: ‘Feeding a narcissist:’ Ukraine reflects on Trump-Putin summit
items.standfirst: Some wins for Russian president, Ukrainian analysts say - although nothing concrete comes out of the meeting.
items.content: Some wins for Russian president, Ukrainian analysts say - although nothing concrete comes out of the meeting.

items.title: Red carpets and flypasts: In Alaska, an indicted war criminal was feted like a king
items.standfirst: For Vladimir Putin, this really couldn't have gone much better. From the red carpet to the flypast - the indicted war criminal was feted like a king.
items.content: For Vladimir Putin, this really couldn't have gone much better. From the red carpet to the flypast - the indicted war criminal was feted like a king.

items.title: Zelensky to meet Trump after US-Russia summit: What to expect?
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Saturday (August 16) that he plans to meet US President Donald Trump in Washington next week after Trump’s summit with Russia’s Vladimir Putin ended without an agreement to end the war in Ukraine. FRANCE 24's James Andre gives us his analysis. What was the outcome of the Alaska summit? What can we expect? "We do not have the parameters of what was actually negotiated during the summit", he said.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Saturday (August 16) that he plans to meet US President Donald Trump in Washington next week after Trump’s summit with Russia’s Vladimir Putin ended without an agreement to end the war in Ukraine. FRANCE 24's James Andre gives us his analysis. What was the outcome of the Alaska summit? What can we expect? "We do not have the parameters of what was actually negotiated during the summit", he said.

items.title: Trump-Putin summit ends with no ceasefire deal
items.standfirst: The anticipated meeting between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin ended without a ceasefire deal in Ukraine.
items.content: The anticipated meeting between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin ended without a ceasefire deal in Ukraine.

items.title: Alaska summit: Putin managed 'to get out of the international isolation'
items.standfirst: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin began with a warm welcome and a flyover by screaming jets at a US military base in Alaska but ended with a thud Friday after they conceded that they had failed to reach any agreements on how to end the Russia-Ukraine war. For more analysis, FRANCE 24's Alison Sargent is joined by Natia Seskuria, associate fellow at Royal Services Institue. 'I think Putin is more of a winner out of this because he managed to get out of the international isolation", she said.
items.content: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin began with a warm welcome and a flyover by screaming jets at a US military base in Alaska but ended with a thud Friday after they conceded that they had failed to reach any agreements on how to end the Russia-Ukraine war. For more analysis, FRANCE 24's Alison Sargent is joined by Natia Seskuria, associate fellow at Royal Services Institue. 'I think Putin is more of a winner out of this because he managed to get out of the international isolation", she said.

items.title: Trump-Putin summit: What could Europe and Ukraine’s next moves be?
items.standfirst: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin began with a warm welcome and a flyover by screaming jets at a US military base in Alaska but ended with a thud Friday after they conceded that they had failed to reach any agreements on how to end the Russia-Ukraine war. For more analysis, FRANCE 24's Alison Sargent is joined by Gavin Hall, teaching fellow in Political Science at University of Stratchclyde and by James Andre, senior reporter.
items.content: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin began with a warm welcome and a flyover by screaming jets at a US military base in Alaska but ended with a thud Friday after they conceded that they had failed to reach any agreements on how to end the Russia-Ukraine war. For more analysis, FRANCE 24's Alison Sargent is joined by Gavin Hall, teaching fellow in Political Science at University of Stratchclyde and by James Andre, senior reporter.

items.title: Trump, Putin end joint press conference without taking questions
items.standfirst: Donald Trump said on Friday (August 15) that he and Russian President Vladimir Putin did not reach an agreement to resolve Moscow's war in Ukraine after a nearly three-hour summit in Alaska, though he characterized the meeting as "very productive." Trump and Putin held a press conference after the summit and took no questions. David Smith, Washington bureau chief for The Guardian, tells us more about the press conference.
items.content: Donald Trump said on Friday (August 15) that he and Russian President Vladimir Putin did not reach an agreement to resolve Moscow's war in Ukraine after a nearly three-hour summit in Alaska, though he characterized the meeting as "very productive." Trump and Putin held a press conference after the summit and took no questions. David Smith, Washington bureau chief for The Guardian, tells us more about the press conference.

items.title: Trump-Putin talks: In Ukraine, 'nobody was expecting much from this summit'
items.standfirst: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin yielded no agreement to resolve or pause Moscow's war in Ukraine, although both leaders described the talks as productive before heading home. What is the general view in Ukraine on how this summit unfolded? FRANCE 24's Emmanuelle Chaze tells us more.
items.content: The high-stakes summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin yielded no agreement to resolve or pause Moscow's war in Ukraine, although both leaders described the talks as productive before heading home. items.title: Trump says Xi told him China will not invade Taiwan while he is in office
items.standfirst: US president says Chinese counterpart told him ‘I am very patient and China is very patient’The US president, Donald Trump, has said that his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, told him China would not invade Taiwan while Trump is in office.Trump made the comments in an interview with Fox News on Friday, ahead of talks with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, over Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin says that an agreement reached will 'pave the path toward peace in Ukraine'
items.standfirst: After greeting President Trump in Anchorage as his “dear neighbor,” Russian President Vladimir Putin opened the evening press conference by saying their agreement will “pave the path toward peace in Ukraine.” He said a permanent deal will require addressing the conflict’s root causes and agreed with Trump that Ukraine’s security must be ensured.
items.content: After greeting President Trump in Anchorage as his “dear neighbor,” Russian President Vladimir Putin opened the evening press conference by saying their agreement will “pave the path toward peace in Ukraine.” He said a permanent deal will require addressing the conflict’s root causes and agreed with Trump that Ukraine’s security must be ensured.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Zelensky will meet Trump in Washington on Monday to discuss ending the war.
• Trump met with Putin in Alaska on Friday, sparking reactions from Ukrainians.
• The meeting follows Trump's summit with Putin, impacting the Ukraine war.
• Papers report on the Alaska summit, focusing on Putin's demands.
• Experts analyze the fallout of Trump's alignment with Putin after the summit.

clusters.title: Canada moves to end Air Canada strike, seeks binding arbitration
clusters.neutral_headline: Canada Forces Air Canada Strike to End
bullet_summary: Reported by Reuters Top News, CBS News, NBC World and others

items.title: Canada moves to end Air Canada strike, seeks binding arbitration
items.standfirst: The Canadian government on Saturday moved to end a strike by Air Canada's cabin crews and require binding arbitration to break their contract impasse, an action that the country's largest carrier had sought but unionized flight attendants fiercely opposed. Thousands of Air Canada flight attendants…
items.content: The Canadian government on Saturday moved to end a strike by Air Canada's cabin crews and require binding arbitration to break their contract impasse, an action that the country's largest carrier had sought but unionized flight attendants fiercely opposed. Thousands of Air Canada flight attendants…

items.title: Government forces Air Canada and flight attendants back to work and into arbitration
items.standfirst: By Rob Gillies and Wyatte Grantham-Philips | Associated Press TORONTO — Canada’s government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during the peak summer travel…
items.content: By Rob Gillies and Wyatte Grantham-Philips | Associated Press TORONTO — Canada’s government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during the peak summer travel…

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants' strike grounds hundreds of planes
items.standfirst: The Canadian government is moving quickly to shut down a strike that has grounded the country's biggest airline. Air Canada flight attendants walked off at the job early Saturday, stranding thousands of passengers across North America and beyond. CBS News New York's Ali Bauman reports on the fallout.
items.content: The Canadian government is moving quickly to shut down a strike that has grounded the country's biggest airline. Air Canada flight attendants walked off at the job early Saturday, stranding thousands of passengers across North America and beyond. CBS News New York's Ali Bauman reports on the fallout.

items.title: News Wrap: Hurricane Erin strengthens into Category 5 storm

items.content: In our news wrap Saturday, Hurricane Erin rapidly intensified into a Category 5 storm in the Atlantic Ocean, rescue crews search for survivors after devastating flash floods and mudslides in Pakistan, and the Canadian government ordered thousands of striking Air Canada flight attendants back to…

items.title: Air Canada grounds flights amid strike, government steps in
items.standfirst: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in. Jobs and Families Minister Patty Hajdu has directed the Canada Industrial Relations Board to impose…

items.content: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in

items.title: Canadian government intervenes in Air Canada flight attendant strike
items.standfirst: The Canadian government on Saturday moved to end a strike by Air Canada flight attendants by asking a labour board to order an arbitration. The strike stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer holiday season.
items.content: The Canadian government on Saturday moved to end a strike by Air Canada flight attendants by asking a labour board to order an arbitration. The strike stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer holiday season.

items.title: Government forces Air Canada flight attendants back to work, into arbitration
items.standfirst: Canada's government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world.
items.content: Canada's government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world.(Image credit: Sammy Kogan)

items.title: Government forces Air Canada into arbitration in bid to end strike
items.standfirst: Jobs minister says full resumption of services could take days, arbitration means 10,000 cabin crew will return to work.
items.content: Jobs minister says full resumption of services could take days, arbitration means 10,000 cabin crew will return to work.

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants strike over pay, grounding hundreds of flights
items.standfirst: Air Canada has suspended all operations as more than 10,000 Air Canada flight attendants went on strike early Saturday after a deadline to reach a deal had passed, leaving its 130,000 daily customers scrambling during the peak summer travel season.
items.content: Air Canada has suspended all operations as more than 10,000 Air Canada flight attendants went on strike early Saturday after a deadline to reach a deal had passed, leaving its 130,000 daily customers scrambling during the peak summer travel season.

clusters.ai_summary:
• The Canadian government moved to end the Air Canada strike on Saturday.
• Binding arbitration was mandated to resolve the contract impasse.
• Thousands of flight attendants walked off the job, stranding passengers.
• The government ordered striking flight attendants back to work.
• The strike caused Air Canada to suspend all operations on Saturday morning.

clusters.title: How Hurricane Erin exploded in strength and became a major storm
clusters.neutral_headline: Hurricane Erin Rapidly Intensifies to Category 5
bullet_summary: Hurricane Erin exploded in strength to a Category 5 storm in the Caribbean before weakening on Saturday, the National Hurricane Center said
Reported by CBS News, Sky News World, BBC World and others

items.title: How Hurricane Erin exploded in strength and became a major storm
items.standfirst: Hurricane Erin underwent rapid intensification to become a Category 5 storm in just hours. It has since weakened to a Category 4 status.
items.content: Hurricane Erin underwent rapid intensification to become a Category 5 storm in just hours. It has since weakened to a Category 4 status.

items.title: Hurricane Erin rapidly strengthens to Category 5 storm - with winds of up to 160mph
items.standfirst: A hurricane making its way across the Caribbean Sea has quickly turned into a Category 5 storm, having rapidly strengthened in just 24 hours.
items.content: A hurricane making its way across the Caribbean Sea has quickly turned into a Category 5 storm, having rapidly strengthened in just 24 hours.

items.title: Erin rapidly intensifies to category five hurricane
items.standfirst: The "extremely powerful" storm "explosively deepened and intensified" overnight, say forecasters
items.content: The "extremely powerful" storm "explosively deepened and intensified" overnight, say forecasters

items.title: Category 4 Hurricane Erin moves past northern Caribbean islands
items.standfirst: Hurricane Erin exploded in strength to a Category 5 storm in the Caribbean before weakening on Saturday, the National Hurricane Center said.
items.content: Hurricane Erin exploded in strength to a Category 5 storm in the Caribbean before weakening on Saturday, the National Hurricane Center said.(Image credit: ‎)

clusters.ai_summary:
• Hurricane Erin rapidly intensified to a Category 5 storm in the Caribbean.
• The storm strengthened in just 24 hours, according to reports.
• Forecasters described the storm as "extremely powerful" and "explosively deepened".
• The National Hurricane Center reported the storm's rapid intensification.
• The hurricane has since weakened to a Category 4 status.

items.title: State Department halts 'medical-humanitarian' visas for people from Gaza

items.content: The U.S. State Department says it's halting visas for visitors from Gaza as it reviews its process for granting visas for medical evacuees. (Image credit: Mehmet Eser)

items.title: State Department Announces Pause on Visitor Visas From Gaza
items.standfirst: The State Department did not specify why it has initiated the review of visitor visas from Gaza, nor how long the review could take.
items.content: The State Department did not specify why it has initiated the review of visitor visas from Gaza, nor how long the review could take.

items.content: State Department move comes as Israel's war and induced-famine in Gaza reach new extremes, with 61,827 killed so far.

clusters.title: Flash floods wreak havoc in northern Pakistan

Reported by Al Jazeera, BBC World, Guardian World and others

items.title: Flash floods wreak havoc in northern Pakistan
items.standfirst: Rescue efforts intensify in flood-hit villages as thousands remain stranded and death toll rises across Pakistan.
items.content: Rescue efforts intensify in flood-hit villages as thousands remain stranded and death toll rises across Pakistan.

items.title: Flash floods kill more than 300 in Pakistan and Pakistan-administered Kashmir
items.standfirst: The majority of deaths were recorded in Pakistan's mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa area.
items.content: The majority of deaths were recorded in Pakistan's mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa area.

items.title: Death toll after monsoon floods in Pakistan rises to more than 320
items.standfirst: Most of the dead were reported in the mountainous province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, with more rain forecastThe death toll from heavy monsoon rains that have triggered flash floods across northern Pakistan has risen to at least 321 people in the past 48 hours, the country’s disaster authority said on Saturday.The majority of the deaths, 307, were recorded in the mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, according to the National Disaster Management Authority. Continue reading...
items.content: Most of the dead were reported in the mountainous province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, with more rain forecastThe death toll from heavy monsoon rains that have triggered flash floods across northern Pakistan has risen to at least 321 people in the past 48 hours, the country’s disaster authority said on Saturday.The majority of the deaths, 307, were recorded in the mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, according to the National Disaster Management Authority. items.title: At least 344 people killed in monsoon flash floods in Pakistan
items.standfirst: The death toll from heavy monsoon rains that have triggered flash floods across northern Pakistan has risen to at least 344 people in the past 48 hours, the country's disaster authority said Saturday.
items.content: The death toll from heavy monsoon rains that have triggered flash floods across northern Pakistan has risen to at least 344 people in the past 48 hours, the country's disaster authority said Saturday.

items.title: Flash floods kill at least 159 people in Pakistan after huge cloudburst
items.standfirst: Search for the missing continues in north-west after downpour also sparks deadly flooding and landslides in IndiaA massive cloudburst has triggered flash floods in north-west Pakistan, killing at least 157 people, as rescuers continued to search for people missing after floods in neighbouring India.Mohammad Suhail, a provincial emergency services spokesperson, said 78 bodies were recovered from various parts of Buner district in the north-west province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa by noon on Friday, and a further 79 were pulled later from the rubble of collapsed homes and flooded villages. Continue reading...
items.content: Search for the missing continues in north-west after downpour also sparks deadly flooding and landslides in IndiaA massive cloudburst has triggered flash floods in north-west Pakistan, killing at least 157 people, as rescuers continued to search for people missing after floods in neighbouring India.Mohammad Suhail, a provincial emergency services spokesperson, said 78 bodies were recovered from various parts of Buner district in the north-west province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa by noon on Friday, and a further 79 were pulled later from the rubble of collapsed homes and flooded villages. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Flash floods have caused widespread devastation in northern Pakistan.
• The death toll has risen to over 300 in Pakistan and Pakistan-administered Kashmir.
• The majority of deaths occurred in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
• Rescue efforts are underway as thousands remain stranded.
• The death toll from the floods has reached at least 344 people.

clusters.title: Serbian police use tear gas against protesters in Belgrade
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests Erupt in Serbia, Police Use Tear Gas
bullet_summary: Reported by NBC World, Reuters Top News, France24

items.title: Serbian police use tear gas against protesters in Belgrade
items.standfirst: Serbian police officers threw tear gas and charged against protesters as tensions escalated between authorities and anti-government protesters in the capital. The country has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.
items.content: Serbian police officers threw tear gas and charged against protesters as tensions escalated between authorities and anti-government protesters in the capital. The country has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.

items.title: Tensions soar in Serbia as angry protesters clash with police and set fire to party offices
items.standfirst: Serbia has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.
items.content: Serbia has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.

items.title: Serbia: Fresh clashes erupt in Belgrade after days of unrest
items.standfirst: Friday brought another episode of tense confrontation between anti-government protesters and police in Serbia. Demonstrators had gathered in front of the army headquarters building in the capital.
items.content: Friday brought another episode of tense confrontation between anti-government protesters and police in Serbia. Demonstrators had gathered in front of the army headquarters building in the capital.

items.title: Serbia's police use tear gas as they clash with anti-government protesters in Belgrade
items.standfirst: Serbia's police used tear gas and crowd control vehicles on Friday evening in Belgrade to disperse anti-government protesters who threw firecrackers and flares at police officers in a third day of clashes. The unrest marked a serious escalation of months of student-led protests that have challenged President Aleksandar Vucic’s hold on power.
items.content: Serbia's police used tear gas and crowd control vehicles on Friday evening in Belgrade to disperse anti-government protesters who threw firecrackers and flares at police officers in a third day of clashes. The unrest marked a serious escalation of months of student-led protests that have challenged President Aleksandar Vucic’s hold on power.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Serbian police used tear gas against anti-government protesters in Belgrade.
• Protests have continued since November, following a train station collapse.
• Tensions escalated as protesters clashed with police and set fires.
• The unrest marks a serious escalation of student-led protests.
• Police used tear gas to disperse protesters in Belgrade.

clusters.title: Israel prepares to move Palestinians to southern Gaza amid protest over war

Reported by CBS News, France24, Al Jazeera

items.title: Israel prepares to move Palestinians to southern Gaza amid protest over war
items.standfirst: The Israeli military body in charge of humanitarian aid to Gaza said the supply of tents and other shelter equipment to the territory would resume on Sunday ahead of the mass movement of Palestinians to the south.
items.content: The Israeli military body in charge of humanitarian aid to Gaza said the supply of tents and other shelter equipment to the territory would resume on Sunday ahead of the mass movement of Palestinians to the south.

items.title: Israeli army prepares to relocate Palestinians to southern Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel on Saturday said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas. Meanwhile the families of Israeli hostages called for a “nationwide day of stoppage” on Sunday to express growing frustration over 22 months of war.
items.content: Israel on Saturday said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas. Meanwhile the families of Israeli hostages called for a “nationwide day of stoppage” on Sunday to express growing frustration over 22 months of war.

items.title: Israel preparing to forcibly displace Palestinians to southern Gaza

items.content: Plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas, amid move to seize Gaza City.

clusters.title: Three states to deploy hundreds of national guard troops to Washington DC
clusters.neutral_headline: National Guard Troops Deployed to Washington DC
bullet_summary: West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days
The protest comes as West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio announced they would deploy hundreds of additional National Guard troops to the nation's capital

items.title: Three states to deploy hundreds of national guard troops to Washington DC
items.standfirst: South Carolina and Ohio join West Virginia in pledging troops, fueling protests that national guard should not be used for ‘a political policing mission’Three states have moved to deploy hundreds of members of their national guard to the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in Washington through a federal crackdown. West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days.The moves announced on Saturday came as protesters pushed back on federal law enforcement and national guard troops fanning out in the heavily Democratic city following Donald Trump’s executive order federalizing local police forces and activating about 800 District of Columbia national guard members. Continue reading...
items.content: South Carolina and Ohio join West Virginia in pledging troops, fueling protests that national guard should not be used for ‘a political policing mission’Three states have moved to deploy hundreds of members of their national guard to the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in Washington through a federal crackdown. West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days.The moves announced on Saturday came as protesters pushed back on federal law enforcement and national guard troops fanning out in the heavily Democratic city following Donald Trump’s executive order federalizing local police forces and activating about 800 District of Columbia national guard members. Continue reading...

items.content: The protest comes as West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio announced they would deploy hundreds of additional National Guard troops to the nation's capital.

items.title: West Virginia, South Carolina, Ohio to deploy National Guard troops to D.C.
items.standfirst: The moves come as federal agents and National Guard troops have begun to appear across the heavily Democratic city after President Trump's executive order earlier this week.
items.content: The moves come as federal agents and National Guard troops have begun to appear across the heavily Democratic city after President Trump's executive order earlier this week.

items.title: National Guard in DC May End Up Carrying Weapons—Report
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump deployed 800 National Guard troops to the nation's capital as part of a crime crackdown in the city.
items.content: President Donald Trump deployed 800 National Guard troops to the nation's capital as part of a crime crackdown in the city.

items.title: West Virginia sending hundreds of National Guard troops to DC at Trump team’s request
items.standfirst: Members of the West Virginia National Guard will be deployed the streets of the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in the District of Columbia through a federal crackdown on crime and homelessness.
items.content: Members of the West Virginia National Guard will be deployed the streets of the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in the District of Columbia through a federal crackdown on crime and homelessness.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Three states are deploying National Guard troops to Washington DC.
• The deployments are part of a federal crackdown on crime.
• Protests are occurring against the federal police takeover plan.
• West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio are sending troops.
• President Trump deployed 800 National Guard troops to the capital.

items.standfirst: Afzal Khan had said visit to Turkish-occupied northern Cyprus was in personal capacity but resigned after furoreCyprus has welcomed the resignation of the UK’s trade envoy to Turkey, Afzal Khan, saying it sends “a resounding message” amid widespread criticism of the Labour MP’s recent visit to the island’s breakaway Turkish-occupied north.Khan had defended his trip on 8 August in a letter to the British prime minister, Keir Starmer, claiming it was conducted “in a personal capacity during the parliamentary recess”.
